words.etymology_text: From Proto-Finnic *äijä, from Proto-Finno-Permic *äjjä. Cognates with slightly differing meanings in several related languages: Sami áddjá (“old male relative”), Erzya оя (oja, “friend”), Udmurt ajy (“father, male”), Karelian äijä (“a lot, great, tall, many”), Ludic and Veps äi (“a lot”).

glosses: mother (woman in relation to her children)

examples.english: Thatcher became lauded as “mother of the nation”.

glosses: mother (respectful title for a nun, usually one who has served for a long time or is the leader of nuns' community)
the letter "Ä" in the Finnish spelling system similar to ICAO spelling alphabet

categories: Pages linking to anchors not found in Appendix:Glossary
words.etymology_text: From Proto-Finnic *äitei (compare Southern Ostrobothnian äitee, äiree), borrowed from Proto-Germanic *aiþį̄ (compare Gothic 𐌰𐌹𐌸𐌴𐌹 (aiþei)). The front vowel in the word could perhaps be explained by influence from baby talk (which has also been suggested as an alternative etymology, compare täti and baby speak äittä-äittä-tättä). The original word for "mother", emä (< Proto-Finnic *emä), is now only used for animals in Finnish but is used for humans in dialects and in other Finnic languages. Cognate with Estonian eit (“old woman”); Võro äide, äidi, ääde (“mother, grandmother”).

glosses: maternity care (work and services performed by maternity care system as contrasted with the system itself)
